awd_titl_txt: The Formation of Undergraduate Engineers as Engineering Leaders
awd_abstract_narration:
Today, leaders of industry and government are calling for increasing numbers of engineering graduates to maintain the nation's economic competitiveness. However, the expected positive impact from increasing the number of engineering graduates will be limited, unless the full capabilities of these graduates are harnessed. Specifically, solving today's complex challenges will require cooperation among experts from many fields. In order for these collaborations to be successful they must harness the diverse capabilities of members of these groups. For that to happen, practicing engineers must exercise technical leadership. Therefore, undergraduate engineering students need to learn how to be effective leaders during their formation as engineers. Unfortunately, engineering educators do not currently have sufficient understanding of how engineering students develop into leaders. This project seeks to improve our understanding of the role leadership plays in the process of becoming an engineer and how to develop an engineering identity in undergraduate engineering students. The project proposes that seeing oneself as an engineering leader requires both the development of an engineering identity in combination with the development of a leadership identity. This project investigates the process of becoming an engineering leader given the central role identity plays in learning.  By understanding the relationship between a leadership identity and an engineering identity, this work will provide a foundation for improving the leadership skills of undergraduate engineers during their time in college using cross-ethnic notions of leadership to serve a diverse student body.

Current approaches in engineering education to develop leadership skills in engineers do little to understand how leadership fits into the broader picture of the heterogeneous nature of engineering work, or the role leadership plays in the formation of an engineering identity. This project seeks to address this gap through a sequential, mixed-methods study resulting in development of a grounded theory of engineering leadership for undergraduate engineering students. The study will answer three research questions: 1) How does leadership identity in engineering students compare to those in other fields? 2) What is the relationship between leadership identity and engineering identity? 3) How do engineering undergraduates define engineering leadership and develop a sense of engineering leadership identity?  This work recognizes that formation of engineers is fundamentally an identity development process. This project combines two models: Lave and Wenger's communities of practice model to understand development of an engineering identity and Komives, et al.'s Leadership Identity Model to understanding how engineering students cultivate a self-concept as a leader. Using these two models, this project seeks to understand how the separate components of engineering and leadership identity converge in the development of a combined engineering leadership identity among undergraduate students. Informed by an analysis of national data, a grounded theory approach will lead to an explanatory model of engineering leadership identity development. As an initial application of the model a series of educational interventions will developed and tested, enabling engineering educators to more effectively train engineering students in leadership.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Today, leaders of industry and government are calling for increasing numbers of engineering graduates to maintain the nation's economic competitiveness. However, the expected positive impact from increasing the number of engineering graduates will be limited, unless the full capabilities of these graduates are harnessed. Specifically, solving today's complex challenges will require cooperation among experts from many fields. In order for these collaborations to be successful they must harness the diverse capabilities of members of these groups. Given their educational background and skillset, engineers should be well positioned to provide this technical leadership within these groups.  However, many have found that engineers are often reluctant to see themselves in these roles. 

 

This project developed new knowledge that gave engineering educators: 1) a better understanding of this reluctance, 2) a theoretical model using identity theories to incorporate leadership into the very core of what it means to be an engineer, 3) a student driven definition of engineering leadership identity, and 4) tested and impactful curricular tools to promote the development of an engineering leadership identity. This knowledge was developed through a multi-phased project. The first phase involved analysis of two large national data sets of college students. This analysis answered two key questions: 1) How does leadership identity in engineering students compare to those in other fields? 2) What is the relationship between leadership identity and engineering identity?

 

On the first question, our work found that engineering students consistently see leadership as less important to their profession and future career than students in other fields (including those in other STEM fields). Findings in the second area were more nuanced.  While our work hypothesized that there was a negative impact on leadership identity (engineering leadership identity) from a robust engineering identity depicted in Figure 1, the results were mixed.  Some analysis showed that engineering students have greater opportunities to engage in leadership development and activities while in college while other analysis highlighted engineering students seeing limited value in their leadership experiences and indicating lower intent to serve as a leader than those in other fields of study. We did ultimately find that engineering identity positively predicted leadership self-efficacy, an encouraging result for educators who intend to tie leadership to engineering professional formation.

 

The second phase of the research project utilized data we collected through focus group interviews with engineering students at three universities: Montana State, University of Colorado – Boulder, and the University of Texas – Arlington. This data was collected to answer our third research question: How do engineering undergraduates define engineering leadership and develop a sense of engineering leadership identity? This work found that students define engineering leadership to be a form of leadership informed by engineering ways of thinking.  This analysis also showed a key limit to developing a robust engineering leadership identity in students is a belief that the leader must possess the greatest technical expertise regarding a problem. Using the findings from the two phases of research we developed and piloted a number of classroom exercises designed to promote development of an engineering leadership identity in both first year engineering students and those nearing the end of their undergraduate education. These exercises were found to develop meaningful (and statistically significant) increases in students’ engineering leadership identities.  Details on the myriad of outcomes from the project are found in the 20+ peer reviewed publications available in the NSF-PAR document repository associated with the project.

 

Beyond the intellectual contributions of the work outlined above, the project generated potentially meaningful contributions to benefit society (the broader impacts). Chief among these is 1) increasing the understanding of how currently underrepresented groups (e.g. Native Americans, women) contextualize engineering identity differently than those from the majority – including an increased focus on becoming an engineer to better be able to give back to community and society and 2) identifying pathways that increase students’ appreciation of the importance of leadership to the engineering profession – including coursework integration and faculty support to overcome the “expert hurdle.” This knowledge was utilized to develop brief coursework activities that promote development of an engineering leadership identity in undergraduate students, thereby increasing their interest in serving as leaders.  This increase promotes greater future leadership roles for engineers, which we expect to broadly benefit society.

 

Additionally, this work spawned three new international collaborations (with two universities in Canada and one in Australia) and published work from the project is now required reading at a second Australian university. This illustrates a varied and broad impact on the way engineering educators are thinking about engineering leadership development.

 


Last Modified: 04/19/2022
Modified by: William Schell
